States¶

  • Input State
  • Parameter State
  • Output State

Overview¶

A State is a component that provides an interface to a projection, and represents the value associated with that projection. There are three types of states, all of which are used by mechanisms and one of which is used by projections, as summarized below.

  • InputState:

    used by a mechanism to represent the input provided by one or more Mapping projections.

  • ParameterState:
    • used by a mechanism to represent the value of a parameter of its function, possibly regulated by a Control Signal projection;
    • used by a Mapping projection to represent the matrix parameter of its function, possibly regulated by a LearningSignal projection.
  • OutputState:
    • used by a mechanism to represent its output, and as the source of any outgoing projection(s):
      • Mapping for a ProcessingMechanism;
      • Control Signal for a ControlMechanism;
      • LearningSignal for a MonitoringMechanism.

Creating a State¶

States can be created used the constructor for one of the subclasses. However, in general, they are created automatically by the mechanisms to which they belong, and/or through specification in context (e.g., when specifying the parameters of a mechanism’s function to be controlled [LINK], or Mapping projections to be learned [LINK]).

Structure¶

Every state is owned by either a mechanism or a projection. Like all PsyNeuLink components, they have the three fundamental attributes:

  • variable: for an inputState and parameterState, this is determined by the value(s) received from the projection(s) that it receives, listed in it the receivesFromProjections attribute; for an outputState, this is the value returned by owner mechanism’s function (and also assigned as the value of the state).
  • function: for an inputState and parameterState, this aggregates the values received by the projections it receives (the default is a LinearCombination function that sums the values); at present, outputState functions are not used (the value of outputStates is assigned directly by the mechanism’s execute method).
  • value: for an inputState and parameterState, this is the aggregated value of the projections it receives; for an outputState, this is assigned by the owner mechanism’s execute method

XXXXX ARE THE ABOVE STATEMENTS ABOUT OUTPUT FUNCTION AND VALUES CORRECT??

Execution¶

States cannot be executed directly. They are executed when the component to which they belong is executed. When an inputState or parameterState is executed, it executes any projections it receives, calls its function to aggregate their values, and then assigns this as its own value. This conforms to a “lazy evaluation” protocol ( see [LINK] for a more detailed discussion).
